nodes.bodyText: Better to use logger if you really need or you can remove the System.out.println from the code

Thanks for reviewing @suthagar23 :)
Actually I'd put this just for convenience in checking the output for now. It isn't intended to be a part of the final commit. Though I'll remove it from the code here and limit it to my local code.

Rather than using a logger (which is a good idea if we were going to output anything) or... manually reading the output, use assertions to check that these are the expected values. That's why they exist.
@ibacher what do you think of @ShivanshRakesh   arranging his data into data sets ?

@HerbertYiga If by this you mean "should this data be stored in a file and loaded from there" my answer would be yes. This should be a different mechanism from loading data into the database, if only because there are a number of layers between the raw data in the database and the narrative that we don't need to worry about here.
Always prefer the should style of naming tests over test to make it clear what the test is testing. For example, I would name this shouldGenerateAnAllergyIntoleranceNarrative.
@ibacher Thanks a lot for this! I myself was looking for alternative ways.

We should get away from referring to "DefaultNarrative". I understand that there's a difference  whether the narrative is generated from the HAPI defaults or ours, but by and large, we don't care about that difference. In my mind, it would almost make sense to break out a new series of classes to test narrative generation alone, so, e.g. having an AllergyIntoleranceNarrativeTest class, etc.
Why is this a separate class?
Actually I thought to keep the generator separate. But I'll move it to the same class with the tests.

Several things:

Comments here are not very helpful. If we need a resource just for testing, it must to be included in the base POM with the <scope>test</scope>. Otherwise, this jar ends up bundled in the OMOD (by default, Maven artifacts are loaded with the scope compile unless you tell Maven otherwise).
We should move away from using GSON at all. HAPI has moved from GSON to using Jackson, which should already be available on the class path.

@ibacher Actually I did not mean it that way. I meant that it won't actually be a part of the final commit.
But yes, I'll remove such code which I don't plan to keep in the final commit, i.e. the google-gson dependency and the print statements. Or maybe if I need it at all, I'll use Jackson as you suggested.

nodes.bodyText: Why not just call this narratives.properties?
Always have a new line at the end of the file. This is primarily to prevent some Git weirdness issues.

nodes.bodyText:
@ibacher PTAL. Doing it this way is fine right?
Using just equalTo(getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(<path>)) raised errors due to type mismatch.

Actually I used IOUtils.readlines() because I just needed the first line, since I had to keep a newline in the end. Though, I guess I can use IOUtils.resourceToString() too and then split it at a newline.
Okay, will restructure the tests.
Did the changes. PTAL.
Thanks for that @ibacher! Sure, will do that.
Have made the changes. PTAL!
Does this not work without the .split("\n")[0]?
No, actually there's an extra newline I added following this. With that, it throws an assertion error.
That makes sense
This should be "classpath:narrative.properties"

@ibacher If I do that, it uses the narratives.properties of HAPI, instead of the local one. So I've moved the resources to a sub-directory org/openmrs/module/fhir2/ inside the resources directory, and changed OPENMRS_NARRATIVES_PROPERTY_FILE to classpath:org/openmrs/module/fhir2/narratives.properties.

Ok. My point was primarily that file: with src/main/resources/... is only going to work in a development environment. Instead of differentiating these two, it might make sense to just use something like classpath*:narratives.properties, allowing us to use other narratives.properties files that exist on the classpath. Basically, we want to be forced to know as little as possible about HAPI.
Ah, I see.
